The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: The TRUE Every Man & Woman THEIR OWN DOCTOR: OR, A SALVE for every SORE.

Being a Book full of Rare Receipts for the moſt dangerous Diſtempers incident to the Bodies of Men, Women and Children; and is very fit to be in all Families againſt any time of Sickneſs, Gathered out of the Library of that famous Traveller Dr. Ponteus and now publiſh'd for the good and benefit of the Kingdom; and being nothing but what is experienced by many thouſands of people in City and Country, doing good to many. Don't read only but practice alſo, then ſpeak as you find; and give God the praiſe in all things.
With Six moſt Excellent Receipts for all ſorts of Cattle whatſoever. Licenſed according to Order.
LONDON, Printed by F. L. for Matthias Drew, Bo- 〈…〉
Living in St. Sepulchres Church yard, and ſold by himſelf, and 〈…〉 Living in Red-Lyon Court in White-croſs-ſtreet. 1676.

div.head: Every Man and Woman their own Doctor
I. For the pain in the Head.
div.p: TAke the greace of a Heart and mingle with Oat-meal and So • and temper them well; then lay it Plaiſter-wiſe to thy temp This is proved.

div.head: II. To Purge the Head.
div.p: TAke the juice of Primroſe, and Milk of a Cow; and with a Q •… blow it into thy Nostrils: and this will Purge thy Head.

div.head: III. For the Megrim in the Head.
div.p: TAke ſour Bread and Chickweed, and bray them together, amboyl them in Vinegar; and ſo bind it to the grieved place: •… take Barley and ſeeth it well in water, and put in Betony, and oth •… good Herbs for the Head, and when they be well ſodden, bind the •… to thy Head: For it is good.

div.head: IV. For a Scald Head.
div.p:
TAke the Liver of a Thorn-back and boyl it by it ſelf; and eight Elecampane Roots, and ſeeth them by themſelves in Spring-water two hours; and put that to four handfuls of Houſe-leek, ſtamped and ſtrained through a Cloth; and make an Oyntment thereof; then anoint t •… Head therewith; and if the Hair be gone, take a handful of Wood and bray it hot to powder; then take two ſpoonfuls of Honey, and anoint the Head therewith where it is pill'd, and thy Hair will ſoo •
• ome again as thick as ever it was before, This has cured many hundred.

div.head: V. For ſore and blood ſhot Eyes, or Rhume, hot or cold.
div.p:
TTake Allom burned, beaten to fine Powder, then take as muc • as will lie on a Groat; So mingle it with half a Spoonful o •
Honey, then drop one or two drops into the Eye when you go to Bed, and you will find help to great admiration: This has Cured many in all my Travels, Probatum eſt.

div.head: VI. A Water to clear the ſight.
div.p: TAke Fennel, Vervain, Roſes, Salendine, and Rue, of each two ounces: and Diſtill them and waſh thine Eyes therewith: this is good for all manner of ſore Eyes.

div.head: VII. For a Pearl and Flegm that grows over the Eyes.
div.p: TAke the Gall of an Hare, and boyl it with as much Honey as the Gall. Probatum eſt.

div.head: VIII. To help the Hearing.
div.p: TAke and Diſtill Sorrel, or Wormwood, in a common Stillary; and take four drops of either of the ſame Waters, which you will; and put into thy Ear Luke-warm.

div.head: IX. For the Rickets in Children.
div.p: TAke as much Jet as will lie upon a Shilling, and ſteep it in half a pint of • ack 4 or 5 hours, then ſtir it about and drink it off, half in the morning, and the reſt at night. This hath done good to many.

div.head: X. For stinking of the Mouth.
div.p: TAke the juice of black Mints, and of Rue a like much, and put it to thy Norſtrils; and this will help thee. This is proved.

div.head: XI. For a Mouth that is ſtaid with heat.
div.p: TAke Ribwort and ſeeth it in Red Wine; and hold it in yo •• Mouth hot: do this often, and be whole.

div.head: XII. To recover a Mans Speech.
div.p:
TAke the juice of Sage and Primroſe, and put into the patients Mouth, and he ſhall ſpeak ſtrait, or within a while after.

div.head: XIII. For a Canker in the Mouth.
div.p: TAke nine Leaves of Sage, and ſtamp them with a little Salt a • Verjuice; and make thereof a Plaiſter, and lay it thereto, and will be whole: but you muſt dreſs it twice a day.

div.head: XIV. To make Teeth white.
div.p: TAke Vinegar of Quinces, and dip a Cloth in it, and rub the Te • and Gums therewith: this ſame faſteneth the Teeth and Gu •… comforteth the Roots of the Teeth, and maketh ſweet Breath.

div.head: XV. To take away the Tooth-ach in half an hour.
div.p: TAke Henbane ſeed, Smallage ſeed and Poppy-ſeed, of each 〈◊〉 weight of a Penny; and make Pellits, with a quantity of Aquavi •• and lay it to thy Teeth that ake: and the pain ſhall ceaſe ſtrait.

div.head: XVI. For a Red Face.
div.p: TAke Sow-thiſtles, Burrage, Purſlain, Sorrel, Barley, Parſley Ro • and Liquoriſh; and boyl all together in running-water: and d •… it firſt and laſt.

div.head: XVII. To make the Face fair.
div.p: TAke the Flowers of Roſemary, and boyl them in White-wine; th • waſh thy Face therewith: alſo the Water of Bean flowers will as well.

div.head: XVIII. For boarſeneſs in the Throat.
div.p:
TAke Penniroyal and ſeeth it in Running-water, and drink a go •… draught two or three nights ſomewhat hot, with a little Loaſ-Su •…
〈◊〉 it; this will make you clear again.

div.head: XIX. For ſore Breaſts.
div.p: TAke a handful of Figgs and ſtamp them, then take a little fre •… Greaſe, and temper it with the Figgs, and make a Plaiſter there and lay it as hot as you can endure it; this will take away the anguiſ • and if it be apt to break it will, or elſe not.

div.head: XX. For the Spleen.
div.p: TAke the Roots of Nettles and ſtamp them well together with Vinegar: and lay it unto the Spleen when it ſwelleth: alſo the Lungs of a Fox dried and made in Powder, and cat in a Figg in the morning is very good.

div.head: XXI. For a stinking Breath.
div.p: TAke three ounces of comin in powder, and ſeeth in Wine, from, 1 Gallon to a Pottle; and drink of it as hot as you can, firſt and laſt; and in ten dayes you ſhall be whole without doubt.

div.head: XXII. To ſtay Vomiting.
div.p: TAke and make a Toaſt, and temper it with Vinegar, and Mints; and ſo hold it to your Noſe: this ſtayeth Vomiting.

div.head: XXIII. For the Running of the Reins.
div.p: TAke Venice Turpentine, ſo make it into Pills, ſo roll them in Cinnamon, and Ginger, and good Loaſ-Shugar, ſo ſwallow them down firſt and laſt.

div.head: XXIV. For the heat of the Liver.
div.p: TAke Liver-wort, ond five-leaved Graſs, Endive, Bugloſs, and Borrage: and ſeeth all theſe in Whey: and drink of theſe as often as you will, and this will help you.

div.head: XXV. For the Black Jaundies.
div.p: TAke Enula Campano Roots, and ſeeth them in Milk; then take the Milk and ſtrain it through a piece of Cotton; and give the Sick to • ink thereof this did help a Gentlewoman that hath been troubled ſix o • Years with it, and could not be helped.

div.head: XXVI. For the Yellow Jaundies.
div.p: TAke Elicampane Roots, and the Inner-bark of a Barbary, of each eight ounces, of Salendine Roots as much, of Saffron the weight of •… oat; ſeeth all theſe in a pint of White-wine, ſtrain it, drink four • onſuls morning and evening, warm.

div.head: XXVII. For the wind Cholick.
div.p: TAke Winter-ſavory, ſtamp it and ſtrain it, with ſtrong Ale; th • drinkwarm, and immediately the pain will ceaſe, as if it we ſwept away: there has been divers helped with this which has ſwoured away two or three times in a day, with the pain thereof.

div.head: XXVIII. For Worms in the Belly.
div.p: TAke the Pills of Oranges and dry them; ſo make them into Powder and drink it in Malmſey, or ſtate Ale, there is nothing better.

div.head: XXIX. For Griping in the Guts.
div.p: TAke Tanſey, Rhue and Sothern wood; and eat it with Salt faſting and be whole.

div.head: XXX. For the ſtone.
div.p:
TAke Acorns that grow on an Oake, and dry them, and make Po •
der thereof; and drink it in the morning faſting, with Rheni • wine and Sugar: this will break the Stone. Probatum eſt.

div.head: XXXI. For the Scyatica in the Hyp.
div.p: TAke a Pottle of Wine-lees, and Wine dregs, and Sour bread Cow-dung; and boyl theſe well together, ſo make a Plaiſte hereof and lay it to the pain as hot as you can ſuffer it: and this will heal you.

div.head: XXXII. For the Gout, and all manner of Aches.
div.p:
TAke of Clot Roots two pound, and ſeeth them in Piſs till they 〈◊〉 tender; and then bray them, and ſtrain them through a Cloth •
hen take ſix Oxe Galls, or Neats, and look that you have a Pottle o • Urine, or more, well ſtrained; then put a quart of Oyl of Olive in, an • ſeeth theſe together till it comes to the quantity of the Oyl: for this w •… work wonders in the Gout.

div.head: XXXIII. To kill Corns on Feet or Toes.
div.p: TAke Roots of white Lillies ſo boyl them in Vinegar, then make it like a Plaiſter and lay it on the Corn, 3 or 4 days and nights and it will make it fall off. But the only thing in the world for Corn is this, if you can take it; which is a black Snail wrapt up in a linne • Cloth, laid before a fire and well roſted, So bind it as hot as you c •• endure it to the Corn and keep it ſupplied with freſh Snails Roſted 2 • 3. nights as need requires, and it will make it dye, and peel off like a Scal and never come again. Proved.

div.head: XXXVI. To drive out the ſmall Po •
div.p: TAke Malmſey, Ginger, and Treacle, and mingle them well together; and when thou goeſt to bed, drink a good drought, and • ill drive out the Pox.

div.head: XXXV For the Cramp.
div.p: TAke two ſpoonfuls of May-butter and two ſpoonfuls of Rhue juyce; and temper them well together till they be a Salve; and anoint the place therewith.

div.head: XXXVI. For the Ague and Feaver.
div.p: TAke the Buds, or Leaves of Willows, Red-ſage, and Fetherfow, of each a handful; ſeeth them in a quart of Milk till the Herbs be well • odden: then cruſh the Herbs, and wring them in a Cloth, and lay them to your Pulſe as warm as you can ſuffer it: and this will help you.

div.head: XXXVII. To make one ſleep well.
div.p: TAke Ground Ivy. and Sengreen, of each a like quantity; and ſtamp them, and temper them well with Womans milk, and lay it to thy Temples; and this will make thee ſleep well.

div.head: XXXVIII. For the biting of a Mad Dog.
div.p: TAke Mints, a Clove of Garlick, and Salt; ſtamp them together and make a Plaiſter thereof and lay to the bitten place, and this will real it.

div.head: XXXIX. To kill a Tetter or Ringworm.
div.p: TAke Fetherfew, ſtamp it and ſtrain it with Vinegar; and rub the Tetter therewith and this will kill it in a ſhort time.

div.head: XL Againſt the Plague.
div.p: TAke three ounces of the Liquor of the Inner-rind of an Aſh Tree, and Still it, with three ounces of White wine; and give the Patient of every three hours; and within twenty four hours, he ſhall be well, by • e Grace of God.

div.head: XLI. For a Cut on the finger or Hand.
div.p: TAke ſome green Hyſop, and ſtamp it well in a Morter, with ſome Sugar; and ſo bind it to thy Hand.

div.head: XLII. For a Conſumption
div.p: TAke the Heart and Lungs of a Call new killed, a Capon; let theſe be bruiſed in a Stone Morter, and boyled with an hundred Snails, till the • oth be as thick as Pottage; put to it Harts tongue, Maiden hair, Hyſop, • bias, Sage, of each an handful, with China Roots ſliced, and beata; two ounces of the Juice of Colts-foot Roots, eight ounces of Blood • a Pig newly killed, and Conſerve of Red-Roſes one pound; theſe being •… ll mixed, let them be Diſtilled with a gentle fire, and reſerve it.

div.head: Six moſt excellent Receipts for all ſorts of Catt •…
For faint Cattle, as well Cow, or Ox. Bull or Steer.
div.p: ONly Vergis is the Remedy given them to drink, and then preſen • into a good Paſture: Or elſe thus, take for every one a Pint •… Verguice, and put thereto a handful of Bay-ſalt, and therewith rub th •… tongues, then let them drink the reſt. This is proved.

div.head: An excellent Drench to be given to Cat-tle at the Spring or fall of the L •…
div.p: TAke hard Soot that commonly is upon the poſts of a Houſe or R •… where the Smoak hath its iſſue, which being beaten into Pow •… with Bay-ſalt, ſeeth the ſame in Running Water, & give it them to dr •… or Rank Ivy, with the Soot and ſalt; and when the Ivy is ſoft, w •… out the juice and ſtrain it and let your Cattle drink thereof blood-w •… Often proved.

div.head: A Soveraign Drink for all manner of Cattle that you ſuſpect to be Lung 〈◊〉
div.p: TAke the Herb that is called Cowſlip, or Lung-woort, and ſta •… it and put thereto Fenerere and mudded with good Ale: and w •… a Horn, or pretty Tunnel Drench either your Horſe, Ox, Cow or Sw •… and it ſhall yield preſent Remedy if there be any Diſeaſe in the Lung.

div.head: Against the Murren.
div.p:
DWarf-Gentian, of ſome called Mock-gillofer, ſmall chopt an •…
ven to Swine and all other Cattle, it preſerveth them wonder •… from the Murren, and all ſuch contagious Deſeaſes as happen to Catt •… corrupt time.
The water which ſtandeth in the hollows of Beeches doth perfe •… Cure the naughty Scurfe and wild Tetters or Scabs of Men, Ho •… Kine, Sheep, if they be waſhed therewithal.

div.head: For a Gald Horſe Back, or Fiſtula, a preſent Cure.
div.p: TAke a quantity of Allom and burn it, alſo a handful of Bar •… more and burn it, then take the powder thereof and mix it •… the Allom, and pour it upon the Sore morning and evening: But i •… Sore be corrupt and full of dead fleſh, then uſe more of the Roch Al • than of the powder of Barly, and when it beginneth to heal, uſe th •… both together, but moſt of the powder of Barly. This is a moſt exce •… Remedy.
